p: Correlation between MR and p1 type of M. pneumoniae has also been reported in studies of recent clinical isolates in China and Korea [ 35– 39]. Probably, the clinical usage of macrolides and dominant p1 gene type trend in these countries are similar to those in Japan. Geographic location may also affect distribution of similar M. pneumoniae strains. However, MR and p1 type did not correlate closely in the studies performed in the United States and other countries [ 40– 42]. In the United States, the MR rate did not change over time despite fluctuations in dominant p1 type [ 42, 43]. The lack of correlation may be attributed to the generally low MR rate in these countries at the time of observation (under 30%), similar to the situation in Japan around year 2000 [ 32, 33]. The preservation of the low MR rate of M. pneumoniae in these countries may be related to the frequency of macrolide usage in clinical treatments in these countries. The selection of MRMPs with specific p1 type has not yet occurred in these countries.
